post_text:
Greetings Families,

As we progress toward the first day of school, things will come up that we need your help with in order to have successful face to face instruction. One of these is transportation. Please consider ways you can get your child/children to school safely other than the school bus. If there is a way, we are asking you to please do that. Our routes are long and there are no breaks along the way. The fewer students we have on the bus the better. As I have mentioned before, a lot of dealing with this issue is going to fall to the adults and if you can help in this instance it will benefit all of us moving forward.

The link below is only for those that will be needing transportation for school. This does not apply to any extracurricular activities. Just home to school. Please complete the survey only if you will be utilizing district transportation for home to school purposes.

https://forms.gle/h2Hib2MPcbmBpjrv7

Thank you and continue to enjoy the summer!
Tom Oâ€™Malley

post_text:
This article, while older, has excellent links to scientific studies. From the article, â€œThe journal Clinical Infectious Diseases published a case study of a boy with Covid-19 who, despite attending three different schools (elementary, language, and a Montessori) and a ski club, and interacting with 172 classmates and teachers while symptomatic, did not transmit the virus to anyone. Australiaâ€™s National Center for Immunization Research and Surveillance published a report with similarly encouraging results of a study in New South Wales: From March to mid-April, 18 individuals in 15 schools were confirmed as Covid-19 cases. Among the 735 students and 128 staff members who were in close contact with those initial cases, just two children became infected. Even more strikingly, â€œno teacher or staff member contracted Covid-19 from any of the initial school cases,â€ the report stated.â€

https://www.wired.com/story/the-case-for-reopening-schools/
shared_text:
WIRED.COM
The Case for Reopening Schools

post_text:
Greetings,

Well, we made it! The school year has ended. Now what? I wish I had a better answer for you than â€œI am not sure,â€ but that is what I have. I know we will look different next year but overall the District will be striving for normalcy in these not normal times.

There will be multiple groups working on this throughout the summer. The plan is to have detailed information out by the end of July or early August. We have received guidance from the California Department of Education and the California Department of Public Health. We will be working with our local public health agency as well. All indications show a large reliance on local information and local decision making. That means our school year will look different than those in Surprise Valley, Susanville, or Fresno.

So stay tuned. We are hoping to see all of our students on August 19. One thing I can promise is that, as always, we will be doing everything we can to keep the students and staff of MJUSD safe.

Have a great summer!
Tom Oâ€™Malley

So stay tuned. We are hoping to see all of our students on August 19. One thing I can promise is that, as always, we will be doing everything we can to keep the students and staff of MJUSD safe.

Have a great summer!
Tom Oâ€™Malley

post_text:
Greetings,

In order to honor the guidance President Trump has issued regarding slowing the spread of COVID-19, we will be committing to the distance learning model through May 1.

We are hopeful to soon have Internet access devices for families that cannot access the Internet. Electronic devices, such as Chromebooks, are being loaned out to families by school site as needed.

We hope to be providing thermometers to families through a partnership with Kinsa. More details to come.

It is very important that your child checks their school email regularly. Also please maintain contact with school Facebook pages.

Please know we miss your kids and we are doing our best to supply what we do daily, but from a distance. Contact your childâ€™s site if you have questions. Make sure to leave a message as the offices are not consistently occupied by staff.

We will get through all of this. Stay positive. Stay home if you can. And wash those hands!

post_text:
Greetings all,

Classes will continue to be suspended next week, 3/30 - 4/3. We will be issuing enrichment work for all of our students on Monday. The schedule for the three sites large sites are included. Also, your students school site will be in touch Friday with more in-depth details.

Our plan moving forward is to release information on Wednesday for the following week of school. It is our hope to have students back as soon as possible!

This is a very dynamic and challenging process and we want to get it right. Thank you for your understanding and patience during these unprecedented times.

During the emergency school closure related to COVID-19, the Modoc Joint Unified School District will make available for pick-up on a daily basis a bag lunch for any children ages K-18.

Distribution of the bag lunches will take place from 11:00 a.m. â€“ 12:00 p.m at the Modoc Middle School Parking lot beginning Tuesday, March 17, 2020- Friday, March 20th. There will be a seperate area for any students who walk. Meals will not be offered during Spring break.

The District will continue to monitor the situation and will update meal distribution information as necessary.

post_text:
Greetings,

Classes at all schools will be suspended for the rest of this week. We will monitor the situation this week and over spring break and then determine how we will be moving forward after break.

For MJUSD employees, an email has been sent with instruction. Please read and/or contact your supervisor.

We are working hand in hand with multiple agencies. It is a very strong group. Rest assured the people of Modoc County are in good hands.

Again, thank you for your understanding during this unprecedented time in our lives. Stay healthy, stay hydrated, stay home if you are sick, rest, and wash those hands!

Point of clarification: The District chose to close schools based on a variety of factors. We were not directed to close. Information continues to roll in by the minute it seems.

We realize the impact on families. This is a very difficult decision, but done in the abundance of caution.

As of Friday, school closures affected 85% of California students. More schools closed throughout the weekend.

Again, thank you for your patience and understanding as we work through this.

post_text:
Greetings all,

Late guidance from the CDC is no groups larger than 50. While this guidance does not effect schools, public health has indicated they are prepared at this time for a closure of the schools.

Therefore all MJUSD schools are closed until further notice. There will be more information today as to timelines.

I am truly sorry for the late notice but things change rapidly these days. Thank you for you patience and understanding as we work through these unprecedented times.

It has been requested by Public Health to suspend all travel out of the District, for students and staff, including sports, FFA, Professional Development and recruitment.

post_text:
Greetings,

Obviously, the Coronavirus is on everybody's mind. Here is a quick update from the District and there will be more information to follow in the coming days.

The District has had plans for a viral outbreak such as this for some time. We are also in contact with the County Public Health Department and will be in close collaboration with them as this situation progresses. At this time there are no cases in Modoc County.

Right now, our best bet is to continue to do what we always do:

-Wash hands often and for at least 20 seconds
-Keep your children home if they are sick
-If your child has a fever, do not send them to school until they are 24 hours fever-free without medication
-Avoid touching your eyes, nose or mouth
-Cover your mouth and nose when coughing and sneezing

As mentioned above, we will have further guidance from Modoc County Public Health soon. Don't hesitate to contact your student's school if you have any questions or concerns.

post_text:
New things are happening at MJUSD!

First, the District Office has absorbed a position and reorganized the office. Our office hours will be 8:00 a.m. - 4:30 p.m. with the office being closed for lunch from 12:30 p.m. - 1:30 p.m.

Second, the District website is up and running! It has been such an exciting and refreshing journey to our NEW and IMPROVED MJUSD website! With that being said, please have patience with us as we continue to update all the sites and provide you with the FRESHEST content! The schools' sites are not yet published, but they will be coming in the near future!

We hope you are having a fantastic summer break and look forward to seeing you on August 21st!

post_text:
Seamless Summer Feeding Option

Modoc Joint Unified School District will once again be serving FREE breakfast and lunch over the summer.

June 17-August 9 - FREE meals are available Monday-Friday at Modoc Middle School, 906 W 4th Street. School aged children, kindergarten through age 18 can participate.

Breakfast: 8:00 a.m. - 8:30 a.m.
Lunch: 12:00 p.m. - 12:30 p.m.

Meals are first come, first serve. No adult meals and no children under TK/K will be served.

For more information, please contact Jessica Boal at (530) 233-7201 ext. 109 or by email jboal@modoc.k12.ca.us.

SAGE STAGE PASSES FOR ANY CHILD NOT ABLE TO GET TO THE MIDDLE SCHOOL CAN BE PICKED UP FROM TEACH, INC.

post_text:
Please see this message from Brian Norby, Principal at MHS:

Today at school a student was searching science fiction weaponry on the internet for a book the student is writing. Another student took a picture of the computer screen and posted the statement â€œdonâ€™t come to school tomorrow.â€ It was reported to the school by another student as a concern, when it was read on Snapchat. During the investigation with law enforcement, the student who posted the image admitted it was sent as a joke and they verified what was being searched on the internet as science fiction. There is no threat to the school or our students.

Message to our students: Consider what you post on social media. It may obviously cause concern for others and may create unintended consequences. If you do witness something that may be a threat, please notify a school employee so we can further investigate.

Thank you
Brian Norby
text:

post_text: Today's tragedy in Texas serves as a reminder that we as students, parents, district employees and community members need to remain vigilant when it comes to the safety of our schools. In incidents such as these, the perpetrator told at least one person of his/her plans 97% of the time. If you have concerns regarding student safety, please contact law enforcement and/or the appropriate site. Thank you!
text: Today's tragedy in Texas serves as a reminder that we as students, parents, district employees and community members need to remain vigilant when it comes to the safety of our schools. In incidents such as these, the perpetrator told at least one person of his/her plans 97% of the time. If you have concerns regarding student safety, please contact law enforcement and/or the appropriate site. Thank you!

post_text: The Alturas Police Department and Modoc County Sheriff's Office do an excellent job of being involved in our schools, visiting and simply being a presence. We are pleased to let you know that officers from the California Highway Patrol will be having a greater presence on our campuses as well. MJUSD appreciates our local LEOs and their willingness to go the extra mile to keep our schools safe. Please thank them!

post_text: The MMS Library gets a facelift through the generosity of the noontime Rotary Club. The Rotary Club purchased two area rugs, a cafÃ© table and chairs, a big comfy beanbag, and a game table. They also painted the entire Library a cheery yellow. They donated the paint for our new mural which was designed by MMS student Karlee Pedrola and painted by art teacher Fawn Waterfield, MHS student Marlana Torres, and several MMS art students. The Rotary also donated 3 Kindles and $2,500 to purchase more ebooks for MMS and MHS. A big thank you to the Rotary!!
text: The MMS Library gets a facelift through the generosity of the noontime Rotary Club. The Rotary Club purchased two area rugs, a cafÃ© table and chairs, a big comfy beanbag, and a game table. They also painted the entire Library a cheery yellow. They donated the paint for our new mural which was designed by MMS student Karlee Pedrola and painted by art teacher Fawn Waterfield, MHS student Marlana Torres, and several MMS art students. post_text: Congratulations to our very own Melissa Royce for being selected as the top educator for the northern California region! She and seven other nominees were honored at a dinner in Chico on January 23rd by the California League of Schools. Mrs. Royce, a math teacher at Modoc High School, has been with the district for six years and is an invaluable asset to our school!
